awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Midnight Temperature Maximum and Its Impact on the Ionosphere-Thermosphere System
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, phenomena in the thermosphere and ionosphere will be studied combining the analysis of observations and modeling. The midnight temperature maximum (MTM) in the thermosphere and related ionospheric phenomena have been observed by multiple instruments but have not been successfully simulated by a physics-based model. This study will improve our knowledge of dynamical and electrodynamical processes in the ionosphere at low latitudes. It will also serve to validate and improve the climatology of wind velocity, neutral temperature, electron density, and electric fields in the whole atmosphere model (WAM). This model will be transitioned into operation for upper atmosphere forecasting and space weather prediction in the near future. A summer student participating in the project will gain experience in data analysis of observations and basic physics of the upper atmosphere.

The WAM is the first comprehensive model that is able to internally generate an MTM of a realistic magnitude. Through simulations using the fully coupled WAM and global ionosphere and plasmasphere model (GIP), this study aims to gain a better understanding of the climatology and morphology of MTM and to investigate its impact on the nighttime ionosphere-thermosphere system. Simulations will provide useful information on MTM in order to interpret the various observations. Multiple ground-based and satellite measurements will be analyzed to infer the longitudinal, latitudinal, seasonal, and solar-cycle variations of MTM and compared with simulation results. Furthermore, ion-neutral coupling between the thermosphere and ionosphere at nighttime will also be investigated.

por.por_cntn:
The funded project focuses on understanding the midnight temperature maximum (MTM) phenomenon in the nighttime thermosphere. This study analyzed the climatology and morphology of MTM from the state-of-the-art numerical model called the coupled Whole Atmosphere Model and Ionosphere Plasmasphere Electrodynamics Model (WAM-IPE). The impact of MTM on the nighttime ionosphere is also investigated. The WAM-IPE results suggest that the magnitude of MTM tends to be larger at the summer hemisphere during the solstice periods, which agrees with various ground-based and space-based measurements. Simulations also show that MTM can lead to the post-midnight equatorial upward drifts at different longitudes that were observed by the C/NOFS satellite. The MTM locally reverses the typical large-scale zonal and meridional wind pattern, in turn affecting the nighttime F-layer electrodynamics. In addition, the longitudinal variation of the drifts in different seasons depends on the magnitude and position of the MTM peak relative to the magnetic equator. Other nighttime phenomena that are associated with the MTM, such as midnight collapse and brightness waves, are also studied using the WAM-GIP. Results show that the localized temperature structure does lead to the reversal of the equatorward meridional wind and cause the decreasing of ionospheric peak height (hmF2). At the same location, model calculated 6300 Å emission shows a strong enhancement that might be associated with the brightness waves that have been observed by the all-sky imagers at various locations. To further understand the MTM, some funding also goes into establishing one of the science goals of INSPIRE-1 (IS-1) CubeSat that is designed and built by LASP at University of Colorado at Boulder. The Compact Ionospheric Probe (CIP) onboard IS-1 will be used to identify the occurrence location and seasonal variability of MTM. IS-1 is expecting to be launched in January 2022.

The study has provided the community a better understanding of MTM and the coupled nighttime thermosphere-ionosphere (T-I) system that have not been well studied. It provides reserach opportinuties to several students and a postdoc. It also allows the PI, who was an early career scientist, to continue growing in the reserach community. Several on-going studies will continue and hopefully provide a deeper understanding of the cause of MTM and how it further impacts the nighttime T-I system.
